message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of bilious vomiting and abdominal distention in a newborn with a distended abdomen and hypoactive bowel sounds suggests intestinal obstruction. Among the options, only defective migration of neural crest cells can cause intestinal obstruction, which can present as Hirschsprung disease. This is supported by the empty rectum on digital rectal examination, which is a hallmark of Hirschsprung disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of bilious vomiting and abdominal distension, along with a radiographic image of a dilated stomach and small bowel loops indicate intestinal obstruction. Defective migration of neural crest cells is the underlying cause of Hirschsprung disease, which is commonly associated with obstructive symptoms in the neonatal period. Disruption of blood flow to the fetal jejunum can cause midgut volvulus, but this typically presents with non-bilious vomiting. Mutation in the CFTR gene is associated with cystic fibrosis, which can cause intestinal obstruction, but this typically presents later in life. Abnormal rotation of the intestine can also lead to intestinal obstruction, but it typically presents earlier in gestation or in the neonatal period.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and imaging suggest malrotation with volvulus, which is caused by defective migration of neural crest cells during embryological development. Disruption of blood flow to the fetal jejunum can also cause volvulus, but the imaging does not show any evidence of ischemia. Mutation in the CFTR gene is associated with cystic fibrosis, which does not present with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and x-ray suggest intestinal obstruction, and the most likely cause is defective migration of neural crest cells leading to Hirschsprung disease. Disruption of blood flow to the fetal jejunum is associated with midgut volvulus. Mutation in the CFTR gene is associated with cystic fibrosis, which can cause meconium ileus but is unlikely to cause bilious vomiting. Abnormal rotation of the intestine may lead to volvulus but is not the most likely cause of bilious vomiting and abdominal distention.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and x-ray findings suggest intestinal obstruction in a newborn, which can be caused by defective migration of neural crest cells leading to Hirschsprung disease. Disruption of blood flow to the fetal jejunum would lead to ischemic necrosis and perforation, and would have been seen on ultrasound. Mutation in the CFTR gene would cause cystic fibrosis, but there are no respiratory or nutritional symptoms. Abnormal rotation of the intestine would lead to volvulus, which would cause a different pattern of bowel dilation on the x-ray.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a possible intestinal obstruction, and the x-ray shows dilated proximal bowel loops. Defective migration of neural crest cells can cause Hirschsprung's disease, which may present with similar symptoms. Disruption of blood flow, mutation in the CFTR gene, and abnormal rotation of the intestine can also lead to intestinal obstruction but are unlikely given the patient's history and presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and imaging findings suggest intestinal obstruction, and among the given options, only defective migration of neural crest cells can result in conditions like Hirschsprung disease, which can cause bowel obstruction in newborns. This is caused by the absence of ganglion cells, which are necessary for proper motility of the bowel. Disruption of blood flow, mutations in the CFTR gene, and abnormal rotation of the intestine can also cause bowel abnormalities, but they do not fit the symptoms and imaging findings of this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and x-ray findings suggest malrotation with midgut volvulus. Defective migration of neural crest cells leads to abnormal rotation of the intestine and is a known cause of malrotation. Disruption of blood flow to the fetal jejunum can also cause malrotation but is less likely in this case as the patient had a patent anus and empty rectum. Mutation in the CFTR gene is associated with cystic fibrosis, which does not present with the symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the x-ray findings suggest malrotation with midgut volvulus, which is caused by defective migration of neural crest cells during embryonic development. Disruption of blood flow, CFTR gene mutation, and abnormal rotation of the intestine can also cause intestinal obstruction, but they are not associated with midgut volvulus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and imaging indicate intestinal obstruction, and among the options, only defective migration of neural crest cells can cause intestinal obstruction in the newborn period. Disruption of blood flow to the fetal jejunum can cause ischemic bowel disease but it is usually diagnosed in utero or in the first few days after birth. Mutation in CFTR gene causes cystic fibrosis, which may cause meconium ileus but not in this case. Abnormal rotation of the intestine may cause midgut volvulus but again, it is usually diagnosed in the first few days after birth.
